comments.commentBody:
Andy, several things:

> What you're talking about is the (re) invention of the turbine engine. Several times the output per pound of engine weight vs piston engines - possible. Several times the output, in an absolute sense - no way.

> To many commentors: the hotter an engine runs, the more efficiently it runs. This is straightforward thermodynamics.

> Your comments about fuel energy density are some of the more insightful ones you've made, in the past couple of years. Add to that: 1 - gas is a binary fuel (i.e. it needs something else - oxygen - to burn...i.e. there's safety, if the fuel can be kept from oxygen). Once a battery starts burning, it's unstoppable, in an energy-sourcing sense. 2 - liquid fuel has an inherent factor of 2X in fuel weight density vs batteries. i.e. our gas tanks are, on the average, half full. Batteries weigh their full weight, whether charged or discharged.

> The holy grail here is not an engine of any type - but a fuel cell.

All in all, not a bad piece. When I started to read, I thought you were going to be talking about the (re) invention of the free piston engine. The (re) invention of the turbine engine is a much more useful exercise.

BTW, in an article from 1-2 years ago, it was claimed this engine "can reduce carbon dioxide emissions by as much as 95 percent in comparison to modern internal combustion vehicle engine".

At least you didn't drink that kool-aid - kudos.

:=)

The argument in favor of using liquified natural gas (LNG) for vehicle fuel is very simply made, thus:

At present, diesel fuel retails in Oklahoma for $3.91 per gallon. This is $27.83 per million BTU energy content.

Natural gas can be obtained in abundance at the Henry Hub price of $4.04 per million BTU energy content.

Fortunes have been made on mark-ups much smaller than this.

Dave (#4),

Combined cycle gas turbines run at 60% efficiency. If the turbine blades would not melt, you could run hotter at higher efficiency. ICEs have similar issues such as pistons ceasing at too high a temperature. But there is no intrinsic limit on efficiency other than that set by conservation of energy: 100%

It amazes me how ancestors warn us of inevitable disasters and how we forget that these disasters will eventually come. Andy - I agree with making energy primary over climate.clarity. But, I don't need further climate clarity and the arguments aren't really about that anyway. They are about protecting failed ideologies on both sides of the aisle. Climate is a convenient distraction for a portion of the populace.

If we simply go back a hundred years and observe the oil focused development of nations we can easily see the negative effects of this energy source. In our case, we have built an economy dependent on other's oil resources. That is translated into the words, "strategic interests". And that gets translated into foreign policy that has warped the world, especially in the Arab states. And they hate us for being their best and worst customer.

So I would rather live in a climate changed world that is at peace and not oil dependent than a carbon free world at war over oil and it's undeniable cheap energy benefits.

Today every American is being asked to sacrifice so that we can prosecute three wars simultaneously. And, those three wars would not exist without oil.

So energy quest, yes, but oil must be first and foremost.

If scientists discovered an asteroid heading towards Earth, would they say it was a hoax?

Would they bicker about the size and affects - while doing NOTHING?

Extraordinary claims require extraordinary proof, and I didn't see any in this article or the accompanying video. Speculation of this sort belongs in Popular Science, not the New York Times. It would be more interesting to read about an engine that has made significant strides toward the claims of its designers.

As for now, there are already a few high gas mileage autos, with the Toyota Prius at the top of that list. With $4 per gallon gas, I can't imagine why they aren't even more popular than they are now. Driving a Prius is like being able to buy gasoline at a 50% discount, It will certainly be my next car.
What is needed is a real time water splliter to produce hydrogen that is used as fuel, while you store water in your tank. Not the hydrogen filling station or fuel cell methods. Till then good luck.
Nice report Andy. I appreciate the fact that it's not divisive.

I don't pay attention to fossil fuel energy companies' claims that they are going to do something in the future- in this case, sequester coal and gas emissions, or burn fugitive methane from gas fracking. They have also said that offshore drilling is now perfectly safe, that we don't really need all those regulations for the mining of coal, and so on.

Let's just address what they are doing today in this country: spewing billions of tons of carbon doixide into the atmosphere, along with vast amounts of SOx, mercury, methane, and particulates. Clean and safe alternatives such as wind and solar are available and deployable at scale.

All that is standing in the way are the fossil fuel companies, along with their puppets in Congress- who recently refused to repeal oil industry subsidies- and the media, which makes statements like "some say global warming is associated with crop failures" (Washington Post). It's going to be up to the people to stop them, via protests, product boycotts, and defeat of the more obvious oil company employees in Congress. And we'd better win this time.

I was completely on-board with the open letter until I got to the "other stuff" section.

We may want to consider that "energy policy" is too big of a bite to chew. The complexity of energy in general is often the reason for inaction. The letter does a great job talking about oil and sets out a clear direction for oil. Everything else isn't so clear.

As a nation we need to wean ourselves from oil, period. And yes, simple metrics around intensity are great for measuring progress. And I agree with the short, mid and long term steps for oil. But, the bottom line should never change, we must become independent of oil sooner rather than later.

It seems that there is a competition going on in the USA, to find the best reasons to reduce US oil dependence and develop alternative energies. I have long given up hope that this talk ever leads to political action.

1. I'm 100% in favor of ratcheting-down the use of crude oil and coal, per unit of GNP. This can be accomplished via a combination of improved efficiency and substitution of clean-energy sources: plug-in hybrids that grab electrons from solar-thermal plants at peak output, and create a reserve for use during the next 24 hours; long-haul trucking converted to natural gas; nuclear; etc.

** See Google's recent investment in a $2 billion solar power plant in the California Mojave Desert, to be completed in 2013. Output = 400 megawatts (peak sunlight), sufficient to power 140,000 homes (natural gas for cooking and heating). One more scale-up step, to a million homes, and we'll have a serious contender for energy production. **

2. However, "regulatory capture", zero-liability government guarantees, and a refusal to be transparent or responsive -- these are guaranteed characteristics of the coal, oil, natural gas, and nuclear industries, into the infinite future.

Here's an article by the highly respected economist, Joseph E. Stiglitz, that discusses the under-lying political power structure:

http://www.vanityfair.com/society/features/2011/05/top-one-percent-20110...

Here's the nut:

"Virtually all U.S. senators, and most of the representatives in the House, are members of the top 1 percent when they arrive, are kept in office by money from the top 1 percent, and know that if they serve the top 1 percent well they will be rewarded by the top 1 percent when they leave office. By and large, the key executive-branch policymakers on trade and economic policy also come from the top 1 percent."

Joseph Stiglitz gives one example (there are a hundred more): "When pharmaceutical companies receive a trillion-dollar gift—through legislation prohibiting the government, the largest buyer of drugs, from bargaining over price—it should not come as cause for wonder."

Larry G.
Seattle, WA

The little known threat of long-term blackouts from solar flare emissions, which NASA calls a potential solar Katrina, are a path to bipartisan energy initiatives.

A nuclear plant that loses power for just two days becomes a major threat!

Ironically, superseding oil, natural gas, coal and Uranium can be accomplished much faster than conventional ignorance might suggest.

Cheap green alternatives are emerging. See for example, Green Light and Moving Beyond Oil at www.aesopinstitute.org

A small flock of Black Swans are being born. These are highly improbable breakthroughs with huge potential impact.

A 24/7 program to validate, develop and produce these practical, cost-competitive, technologies takes little more than well supported entrepreneurs.

No nation on earth has more of them. The missing ingredient has been adequate adventure capital, as Black Swans always find it hard to be taken seriously, until they no longer need liquidity.

For example, look at the history of cold fusion. Dismissed by almost every scientist, it now is emerging as a cost-competitive alternative to all fossil fuels and Uranium.

See Cold Fusion on the same Aesop website to learn more about this remarkable breakthrough than you probably want to know.

Coal, oil, natural gas and Uranium can be cheaply surpassed by green systems that are inherently much safer and in abundant supply.

The time has come to focus on the truly practical alternatives that have been difficult to take seriously.

As the Wright Brothers opened a new era in flight, Andrea Rossi has produced a practical beacon to lead us out of our energy morass.

And the impact on the economy will be hard to beat. Here come the missing jobs in great numbers!

Imagine the economic effect of cars and trucks that can sell electricity to local utilities when suitably parked and might pay for themselves! They could be practical within perhaps 3 to 5 years with an all-out effort.

Two points,

The USA is about to get back into the oil/coal and gas business in a very big way. We are about to drill (on and offshore and in deep-water)/frack/mine our way to lower our dependence upon imported oil dramatically. This will be a large enough effort to move unemployment numbers in a positive direction (although this could be offset by a weakening of the economy). We are, also, about to get back to manufacturing our own goods with our own energy. We will continue to pursue this path until we have fully-viable alternatives, this will be decades at least. While we can all support the replacement of these traditional fuels, to do so irrationally or based upon failed conjecture is a no-go with an economically ravaged world. When they make sense, they will simply out-compete and will prevail.

As there remains zero evidence or proof that carbon emissions from any source have affected or will affect climate, any paper or work that assumes this is working from theory or speculation or in focus on The Precautionary Principle. Perhaps it would be more accurate and responsible then to add to your descriptions words which clarify that the assumptions used in these works or assertions are theoretical, conjectural or speculative. Not to do so, where there is no evidence to support said assertions and when faced with factors such as an 80 year deceleration of the rate of sea-level rise into the face of 80 years of additional carbon hollers out to anyone watching the science that something is dramatically wrong in the land of 'more carbon=more heat= rising seas' aka the 'settled science' of climate change - isn't correct or the long-term (larger than multi-decadal oscillations such as the period between 1976 and 1999 +/-) sea-level rise would be accelerating and it simply is not.

"Working with the complete monthly-averaged records of 57 U.S. tide gauges archived in the Permanent Service for Mean Sea Level data base that had lengths of 60-156 years (with a mean time span of 82 years), however, they determined that there had not been any acceleration in the rate-of-rise of the sea level along the shorelines of the United States over that period of time, during which interval the world's climate alarmists claim the planet had warmed at a rate and to a level that were unprecedented over the past one to two millennia. Quite to the contrary, in fact, they detected a slight deceleration of -0.0014 mm/year/year. And working with 25 of the tide gauge records that contained data for the period 1930-2010, they calculated an even larger deceleration of -0.0130 mm/year/year.....also report that they "obtained similar decelerations using worldwide-gauge records.....they rhetorically ask why the concomitant worldwide-temperature increase "has not produced acceleration of global sea level over the past 100 years," and, indeed, "why global sea level has possibly decelerated for at least the last 80 years."" [Houston, J.R. and Dean, R.G. 2011: Journal of Coastal Research]"
